meanings.definition: To fill (something) by force with more than it can easily hold.
meanings.sent1: I had to cram all my clothes into the tiny suitcase.
meanings.sent2: The students tried to cram too many books onto the shelf.
meanings.sent3: The squirrel tried to cram all the nuts into its mouth at once.
meanings.sent4: The overflowing river began to cram debris against the bridge.
meanings.sent5: The clown attempted to cram an entire watermelon into his pocket.

meanings.definition: To study intensively over a short period of time.
meanings.sent1: She had to cram for the test the night before.
meanings.sent2: The students decided to cram for the exam in the library.
meanings.sent3: The cat tried to cram all the information into its tiny brain.
meanings.sent4: The athlete had to cram all the plays into his head before the game.
meanings.sent5: The scientist had to cram years of research into a single presentation.

meanings.sent1: The hungry child would cram cookies into his mouth.
meanings.sent2: The raccoon would cram as much food as possible into its cheeks.
meanings.sent3: The dog tried to cram the entire steak into its mouth at once.
meanings.sent4: The birds would cram seeds into their beaks before flying away.
meanings.sent5: The guests would cram the delicious buffet food onto their plates.
